  I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 

I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka for the third additional financing of the Small and 
Medium-Sized  Enterprises  Line  of  Credit  Project.  The  report  also  describes  the  proposed 
administration of a grant to be provided by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction (JFPR) for the 
third  additional  financing  and  the  proposed  administration  of  technical  assistance  (TA)  to  be 
provided by the JFPR for Value Chain Development for Tea Sector, and if the Board approves 
the  proposed  loan,  I,  acting  under  the  authority  delegated  to  me  by  the  Board,  approve  the 
administration of the grant and the TA. 
 

 

To promote financial inclusion of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Sri Lanka, 
which is  a key development  priority  for the  government to  reduce unemployment  and regional 
inequalities, and provide immediate financial support to severely affected SMEs in response to 
the  coronavirus  disease (COVID-19)  pandemic, the  third  additional  financing  will  scale up  and 
change the scope of the project to (i) expand and deepen the banks’ outreach to underserved 
SMEs,  including  businesses  led  by  women  and  tea  smallholders;  and  (ii)  provide  affordable 
working capital loans to severely affected SMEs to support their business continuity and recovery. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

 
A. 
 

Rationale 

 

The  project  was  originally  approved  by  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  Board  of 
Directors  on  15  February  2016  with  a  loan  and TA  to strengthen  access  to  finance  by  SMEs, 
which account for more than 45% of total employment and 52% of gross domestic product.1 The 
project prioritizes continued support for women-led businesses and export-oriented industries in 
Sri Lanka to address the chronic issues of women’s low level of economic participation and the 
declining international competitiveness of traditional industries, such as tea.2 
 

 

The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly affected Sri Lanka. Sri Lanka promptly imposed 
social distancing and containment measures in March 2020, which helped curb the spread of the 
virus in  the  country—recording  zero  community  transmission  since  1 May  2020.  However,  the 
country saw sudden spikes in COVID-19 cases in early October 2020. The total number of people 
who  had  tested  positive  for  COVID-19  sharply  increased  from  3,402  as  of  4  October  2020  to 
12,570  as  of  6  November  2020. 3  To  control  the  spread  of  the  new  wave,  the  government 
reintroduced stricter social distancing measures and imposed curfew in some areas of the country 
including Colombo and two other districts in Western Province, which is the center of economic 
activity in the country.  
 

 

In terms of the economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, tourism and other export-
oriented  industries  were  the  first  to  be  severely  affected  since  early  2020  because  of  a  sharp 
decline in global demand and supply chain disruptions, which led to an economic slowdown that 
gradually  spread  across  a  wide  range  of  sectors  and  were  deteriorated  through  the  social 
distancing and containment measures. SMEs face serious challenges to their survival because

Progress of Ongoing Project

capital resources (OCR), became effective on 27 April 2016.5 This was a financial intermediation 
loan  allocated  to  10  participating  financial  institutions  (PFIs)  for  eligible  SME  subprojects.  The 
original loan demonstrated quick disbursements, exceeding development targets (Table 1), and 
improved access to finance for targeted SMEs.6 The original loan was closed on 10 January 2019 
with full deployment, 1.5 years earlier than the initial plan. 
 

 

First  and  second  additional  financing.  An  additional  $75  million  loan,  financed  from 
ADB’s  OCR  (the  first  additional  financing,  the  second  loan),  and  a  $9.5  million  grant  from  the 
Women Entrepreneurs Finance Initiative (We-Fi) (the second additional financing) were approved 
in  2018.7 The  additional  loan  scaled  up  the  original  project  size  and  the  additional  grant  has 
enhanced  women  entrepreneurs’  access  to  risk  capital.  The  We-Fi  grant  was  cofinanced  with 
ADB’s  second  loan to  provide  20%–35%  principal  paydown  for  eligible  SME  borrowers  led  by 
women under ADB’s line of credit (We-Fi financing scheme). The additional loan and grant have 
been performing well, with the sharp increase in the number of SME borrowers led by women 
(Table 1) partly because of the We-Fi grant provisions of $6.46 million to 658 SMEs led by women.

has been rated on track since its approval. The ongoing project (i) remains technically feasible, 
economically viable, and financially sound; (ii) is accorded high priority by the government; and 
(iii)  is  consistent  with  the current  project’s  development  objectives, the  government’s  priorities,

expected outputs and the management of risks are rated successful (footnote 8). 
 

2. 

Proposed Third Additional Financing 

 

 

Given the good performance of the ongoing project, the government has requested a third 
additional financing to scale up and introduce certain changes to the existing project to (i) fund 
immediate working capital needs of SMEs in response to COVID-19, and (ii) enhance the access 
to long-term financing by underserved SMEs (such as SMEs led by women and tea smallholdings) 
to support economic recovery and transformation. The third additional financing of $166.25 million 
will be delivered through 3 components under output 1: (i) a $45 million SME credit line (SME 
component) for deepening the SME finance ecosystem and promoting women entrepreneurship, 
(ii)  a  $21.25  million  affordable  credit  facility  for  promoting  financial  inclusion  of  strategically

Small and medium-sized enterprises component: Enhancing financial access and 
promoting women entrepreneurship. The continuation of ADB’s credit line will accelerate the 
PFIs’ transformation toward sustainable banking and, in turn, encourage growth-oriented SMEs 
to embark on business expansion. The continuation of the We-Fi financing scheme for SMEs led 
by  women  will  be  promoted  under  an  upgraded  government  policy  framework  for  women 
entrepreneurship  development  (paras.  8  and  10).12 The  eligibility  criteria for  subprojects  of  the 
SME  component  and  We-Fi  financing  scheme  have  been  reconsidered  for  more  targeted 
interventions,  with  more  effective  utilization  of  ADB’s  long-term  financing  and  the  remaining 
$2.95 million We-Fi grant (paras. 32 and 35). 
 

 

Pilot component: Support for tea smallholders. Among various export-oriented sectors 
in Sri Lanka, the tea industry has been an important part of the socioeconomic fabric. It accounts 
for  15%  of  exports  and employs  10%  of  the  workforce,  most  of  whom  are  less  educated  with 
chronically  low  income.  Some  75%  of  tea  production  depends  on  more  than  400,000  tea 
smallholders,  defined  as  tea  farmers  with  landholdings  of  no  greater  than  20.2  hectares  (50 
acres).  Most  tea  smallholders  are  engaged  in  informal  family  businesses.  Despite  its  brand 
recognition, Sri Lankan tea has recently been losing its international competitiveness because of 
the declining quality and quantity of tea leaves resulting from underinvestment.13 Tea bushes are 
aged without regular replanting. The current replanting rate of the tea smallholding segment is 
only  0.7%,  while  the  ideal  rate  is  2%–3%.  Technological  upgrading  in  agricultural  practices, 
including climate change adaptation, is low. The underinvestment by tea smallholders is caused 
by (i) their limited access to long-term financing to match their yield curve;14 (ii) their limited access 
to training, technology, and markets; and (iii) ineffective enabling policy frameworks. To address 
these issues, the affordable credit facility will support tea smallholders’ new investments, which 
will  be  complemented  by  a  new  attached  TA  (paras.  38–39)  for  developing  an  enabling 
environment for the tea industry. 
 

 

Emergency response component: Support for small and medium-sized enterprises 
affected by COVID-19. SMEs are more vulnerable in times of economic downturn because they 
(i) are too small to downsize, (ii) are less diversified in their economic activities, (iii) have lower 
capitalization and working capital buffers, and (iv) experience a lack of various financing options.

restructuring  their  SME  loans  and  extending  moratoriums  for  SME  debt  repayments  until  31

January 2020 (footnote 4). Despite SMEs’ acute financing demands for business continuity, banks 
face difficulty in (i) lowering their lending rates to a level that would be affordable to SMEs in the 
current environment, owing to the banks’ higher cost of funds; and (ii) providing new loans, owing

In late March 2020, the CBSL announced a new SLRs50 billion concessional financing 
scheme for all SMEs and large enterprises in tourism and other export-oriented sectors to cover 
2  months  of  their  obligatory  expenses,  such  as  salary  payments.  The  CBSL  scheme  was

a more targeted approach is needed to provide adequate liquidity for SMEs, some of which may 
not have sufficient fixed assets for collateral, to restart their businesses. 
 

 

This situation will likely lead to the following negative consequences. In the short term, 
(i) banks will incur losses from provisioning of increased nonperforming loans and from voluntary 
interest  concession  to  SMEs;  and (ii)  SMEs  without  sufficient  revenue  will  accumulate  a  high-
interest debt burden, cannot roll over existing loans, and become insolvent. In the medium term, 
there is a risk that the banks’ decreased lending capacity could weaken financial intermediation, 
which would hinder economic recovery and transformation. To address the short-term issues, the 
ERC will establish an affordable short-term financing facility in December 2020. To address the 
medium-term risk, the repayments from the ERC will be reallocated to the SME component and/or 
the pilot component from 2022 (para. 28) for providing long-term financing to underserved SMEs. 
 

 

ADB’s  continued  long-term  engagement  through  these  three  components,  with  the 
ongoing and new TA projects, will ensure a holistic approach to effectively evolve an overall SME 
finance ecosystem based on the foundation developed under the ongoing project (paras. 6–10).15 
 
B. 
 

Impact and Outcome 

 

The  project  is  aligned  with  the  following  impact:  employment  opportunities  for  SMEs 
increased.16 The project will have the following outcome: SMEs’ access to finance strengthened.17 
 

 

The project’s impact and outcome statements are unchanged as a result of the additional 
financing. However, as illustrated in the revised design and monitoring framework, each of the 
three  credit  lines  delivered  under  the  third  additional  financing  and  the  attached  JFPR  TA 
establish revised and new outcome indicators, which reflect their respective targeted objectives. 
 
C.

revision  in  the  output  4  statement.  The  third  additional  financing  will  scale  up  and  expand  the 
scope under outputs 1, 3, and 4 of the overall project (paras. 22–24). Outputs 2, 5, and 6 will be 
retained.  
 

 

Output  1:  Financing  to  small  and  medium-sized  enterprises  through  formal 
intermediaries increased. The SME component will scale up and refocus the ongoing project 
by delivering additional  financing  to support the credit  line  to  SMEs to address their  long-term

IV. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

Economic and Financial 

 

The project is economically and financially viable.28 Economically, it will (i) meet the urgent 
financing needs of SMEs affected by COVID-19 and (ii) promote the PFIs’ mainstreaming of their 
SME operations. Financial support for unbanked businesses led by women and tea smallholders 
through We-Fi and JFPR grants will have positive economic externalities. Financially, the PFIs 
will  assess  the  credit  risk  of  each  subproject.  The  10  PFIs  are  financially  sound,  given  their 
compliance with the stringent regulatory capital and liquidity requirements under Basel III, which 
will ensure their resilience to external shocks including COVID-19.

project. Mitigating measures include (i) frequent monitoring of subprojects by ADB and the PMU, 
and (ii) briefings to PFIs on reporting and audit requirements following ADB’s applicable policies 
and  their  strict  enforcement.  With  these  measures,  the  overall  financial  management 
arrangements are considered adequate. ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) 
was  explained  to  and  discussed  with  the  government  and  the  MOF.  The  specific  policy 
requirements and supplementary measures are described in the PAM.
